p: Similar to gut microbiome studies, gut virome studies begin by isolating the genetic material from intestinal specimens (Fig. 3). Given the perceived predominance of DNA viruses in human stool [ 14, 15], current virome studies mainly use DNA extraction from fecal samples [ 78– 80]. However, the current conception of gut virome composition might underestimate the abundance of RNA viruses. For example, RNase I is commonly used in VLP isolation protocols to remove free capsid-unprotected RNA of non-viral origin [ 78, 79]. However, RNase I has recently also been shown to affect the RNA-fraction of the virome [ 84]. To get a true estimate of the RNA viruses in the sample, one needs to restrict the use of RNase I, although this might come at a cost of increased contamination (Table 2).
